@marccwr @GAFO666 @Ripple Hi Marc, TIPS is being developed as a multi-currency solution. It will be launched for euro payments in November, but it is possible for other currencies to join.

We are developing #TIPS, a service that will make it easier for more banks to offer instant payments. Read our article about all the benefits banks will enjoy when they sign up for #TIPS https://t.co/CpgltYuVjC https://t.co/Oee4zxepv8

Thanks for your votes and replies! We think euro payments should be faster for everyone. Well, there’s good news… instant payments are coming! Learn more about instant payments in our explainer (available in 23 languages) https://t.co/71CtrNVjo3 https://t.co/7lDJsbpNpd

Interested in finding out more what structural reforms are and why the ECB cares about them? Read our explainer https://t.co/QNv8QcyvD7 6/6

It is primarily national governments who are responsible for policies that support the well-being of their citizens. EU institutions can contribute by ensuring a level-playing field and completion of the Single Market, as well as by attaching incentives to European support. 5/6
Structural reforms are also important for the effectiveness of monetary policy and bring the euro area closer to the requirements of an optimum currency area. 4/6

Structural policies which support equity financing and cross-country asset diversification, along with reforms that increase flexibility, enhance economic resilience in the euro area and reduce the high social costs associated with adverse shocks. 3/6

Improving the quality of institutions by enhancing the rule of law and reducing corruption can strongly boost economic performance and social welfare. Recent reforms in labour and product markets are supporting growth and employment, but much more can be done. 2/6 https://t.co/aSgLw17SgN

(THREAD) There are many opportunities in euro area countries for further structural reforms that would boost growth and support social fairness. This thread summarises the findings of a new ECB Occasional Paper on this subject (full paper: https://t.co/qPqRDDbSI0) 1/6 https://t.co/uyWhGQquff

Draghi on monetary policy after the end of net asset purchases. [8/9] https://t.co/f4q09lUhd1

Draghi: Our enhanced forward guidance clearly signals that we will remain patient in determining the timing of the first rate rise and will take a gradual approach to adjusting policy thereafter. [7/9]

Draghi: We anticipate that after September 2018, subject to incoming data confirming our medium-term inflation outlook, we will reduce the monthly pace of the net asset purchases to €15 billion until the end of December 2018 and then end net purchases. [6/9]
Draghi: Last week the Governing Council concluded that progress towards a sustained adjustment in inflation has been substantial so far. [5/9]
Draghi: We had set out three conditions that must be in place for our net asset purchases to end. [4/9] https://t.co/kdvHXh6XXe

Draghi: Regarding our monetary policy, progress towards a sustained adjustment in inflation has been substantial so far. To maintain this, monetary policy in the euro area must remain patient, persistent and prudent. [3/9]
Draghi: The euro area’s economy continues on a growth path and inflation is gradually returning towards our objective. But uncertainty permeates the economic outlook. [2/9]
